A particle having mass \(m\), kinetic energy measured in the Lab frame collides head-on with a stationary nucleus of mass \(M\). If \(K_{\text{cm}}\) is the total kinetic energy of the system with respect to the centre of mass frame, then show that \[K_{\text{cm}} = \left( \frac{M}{M+m} \right) K_{\text{Lab}}\] If \(K_{\text{cm}}\) is the total kinetic energy of the centre of mass in the lab frame, show that \[K_{\text{cm}} = \left( \frac{m}{M+m} \right) K_{\text{Lab}}\] If \(K_{\text{th}}\) is the minimum kinetic energy (threshold energy) to cause an endoergic reaction in the above situation, show that \[K_{\text{th}} = -Q \left(1 + \frac{m}{M} \right)\]

A particle having mass \(m\), kinetic energy measured in the Lab Frame collides head-on with a stationary nucleus of mass \(M\). Let \(K_{\text{wrt cm}}\) be the total kinetic energy of the system with respect to the centre of mass frame (i.e., the energy available to cause the reaction). Let \(K_{\text{cm}}\) be the total kinetic energy of the centre of mass in the lab frame. If \(K_{\text{th}}\) is the minimum kinetic energy (threshold energy) required to cause an endoergic reaction, answer the following questions using both the Lab frame (L-frame) and the Centre of Mass frame.
(a) Show that the total kinetic energy of the system with respect to the centre of mass frame is given by \[ K_{\text{wrt cm}} = \left( \frac{M}{M + m} \right) K_{\text{Lab}} \].
questions.sText: The velocity of the centre of mass of the system is \[ v_{\text{cm}} = \frac{mv + M(0)}{m + M} = \frac{mv}{m + M}. \] Let \(v'_m\) be the velocity of mass \(m\) with respect to the centre of mass and \(v'_M\) be the velocity of mass \(M\) with respect to the centre of mass. Then \[ v'_m = v - v_{\text{cm}} = v - \left( \frac{mv}{m + M} \right) = \frac{Mv}{m + M}, \] and \[ v'_M = 0 - \frac{mv}{m + M} = -\frac{mv}{m + M}. \] In the centre of mass frame, the kinetic energy is \[ K_{\text{wrt cm}} = \frac{1}{2} m (v'_m)^2 + \frac{1}{2} M (v'_M)^2. \] Substituting the above expressions, \[ K_{\text{wrt cm}} = \frac{m}{2} \left( \frac{Mv}{m + M} \right)^2 + \frac{M}{2} \left( \frac{mv}{m + M} \right)^2. \] This simplifies to \[ K_{\text{wrt cm}} = \frac{1}{2} \left( \frac{Mm}{m + M} \right) v^2 = \frac{1}{2} \mu v^2, \] where the reduced mass \(\mu\) is given by \[ \mu = \frac{mM}{m + M}. \] Since \( K_{\text{Lab}} = \frac{1}{2} m v^2 \), we obtain \[ K_{\text{wrt cm}} = K_{\text{Lab}} \left( \frac{M}{m + M} \right). \]

questions.qText: (b) Show that the total kinetic energy of the centre of mass in the lab frame is given by \[ K_{\text{cm}} = \left( \frac{m}{M + m} \right) K_{\text{Lab}} \].
questions.sText: The kinetic energy of the centre of mass is \[ K_{\text{cm}} = \frac{1}{2} (m + M) v_{\text{cm}}^2. \] Substituting \( v_{\text{cm}} = \frac{mv}{m + M} \), we get \[ K_{\text{cm}} = \frac{1}{2} (m + M) \left( \frac{mv}{m + M} \right)^2. \] This simplifies to \[ K_{\text{cm}} = \frac{1}{2} \left( \frac{m^2 v^2}{m + M} \right) = \frac{1}{2} m v^2 \left( \frac{m}{m + M} \right). \] Since \( K_{\text{Lab}} = \frac{1}{2} m v^2 \), we obtain \[ K_{\text{cm}} = K_{\text{Lab}} \left( \frac{m}{m + M} \right). \]

questions.qText: (c) If \(K_{\text{th}}\) is the minimum kinetic energy (threshold energy) required to cause an endoergic reaction, show that \[ K_{\text{th}} = -Q \left( 1 + \frac{m}{M} \right). \]
questions.sText: From the Lab frame, the kinetic energy of the centre of mass is \[ K_{\text{cm}} = K_{\text{Lab}} \left( \frac{m}{m + M} \right). \] This energy is carried by the centre of mass and is therefore not available to be dissipated in the reaction. Hence, the available energy is \[ K_0 = K_{\text{Lab}} - K_{\text{cm}} = K_{\text{Lab}} \left( \frac{M}{m + M} \right). \] For an endoergic reaction, the available energy must be equal to the magnitude of the \(Q\)-value, i.e., \( K_0 = -Q \). Thus, \[ K_{\text{Lab}} \left( \frac{M}{m + M} \right) = -Q. \] Solving for the threshold kinetic energy, we obtain \[ K_{\text{th}} = -Q \left( 1 + \frac{m}{M} \right). \]
